summary: Email chain between US and UK officials discussing challenges in obtaining an interview with Prince Andrew via Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty (MLAT) request. The UK Home Office raises concerns about predication for questioning Andrew and potential judicial review by his lawyers, while US officials argue voluntary cooperation efforts have been exhausted.

persons.name: Andrew
persons.context: Prince Andrew is the subject of the MLAT request regarding his knowledge of or involvement in criminal conduct related to Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Dawn Browne
persons.context: UKCA official involved in discussions about the MLAT request and potential judicial review challenges.

persons.name: Philomena Creffield
persons.role: Deputy Director & Head of UK Central Authority
persons.context: Senior Home Office official corresponding about the MLAT request and noting potential high-level meetings.

persons.name: Gary Bloxsome
persons.context: Lawyer from Blackfords representing Prince Andrew in communications with US officials about voluntary cooperation.

persons.name: Julian Gibbs
persons.context: UK Central Authority recipient of email correspondence about the MLAT request.

persons.name: Margaret
persons.context: Recipient of email correspondence about the MLAT request status.

persons.name: Amanda J. Chadwick
persons.context: CC'd recipient of email correspondence about the MLAT request.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Central figure in the criminal investigation for which Prince Andrew's knowledge is being sought.

connections.description: Bloxsome represents Prince Andrew through the law firm Blackfords in communications with US officials.
Both are UK Home Office officials working on the MLAT request regarding Prince Andrew.
Engaged in discussions about MLAT procedures and challenges regarding Prince Andrew interview.
Prince Andrew's knowledge of or involvement in criminal conduct related to Epstein is under investigation.

events.title: MLAT Request Discussions
events.description: Ongoing discussions between US and UK officials about executing an MLAT request to interview Prince Andrew regarding Jeffrey Epstein case.

events.title: Voluntary Cooperation Offer
events.description: Prince Andrew's lawyers offered voluntary cooperation in early June, which UK officials cite as reason to delay MLAT request.

events.title: Initial Correspondence with Blackfords
events.description: Beginning of correspondence between US case team and Prince Andrew's lawyers regarding voluntary interview.

events.title: Blackfords Refusal to Assist
events.description: Blackfords stated in writing that 'there is no purpose to be served in continuing to try to assist further'.

locations: Home Office, 2nd Floor, Peel Building, 2 Marsham Street, London SW1P 4DF
keyFacts: UK Home Office officials expressed concerns about predication for questioning Prince Andrew, stating facts on his involvement were 'pretty thin'.
UK officials anticipated Blackfords (Prince Andrew's lawyers) would file a judicial review challenging the MLAT request if voluntary cooperation hadn't been exhausted.
US officials argued that requiring exhaustion of voluntary avenues before MLAT requests conflicts with the US-UK treaty and would affect many cases.
There was a 'significant mutual lack of trust' between the US case team and Prince Andrew's lawyers, making voluntary cooperation unlikely.
Prince Andrew's team had offered voluntary assistance several months prior and again after learning of the MLAT request.
